result.execSummary:
The defendant Matthew C. Wallace was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Manufacture/Deliver Heroin (<3g) [Modifiers: On or Near a School], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(d)1.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt:
Case called at 2:15 pm
Defendant Matthew C. Wallace in court, in custody with Attorney Elizabeth F Svehlek.   appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Court examines the Defendant as to rights, understanding & intent.  
Mr. Wallace waives his right to Preliminary Hearing; the Court accepts this waiver and binds him over for Arraignment.
State files information

Arraignment:
--service of Information admitted, reading waived

Constitutional rights reviewed; maximum penalties recited; plea of "Guilty" entered; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified; Court finds the plea has been entered freely, voluntarily, intelligently and accepts the plea, finds the Defendant  guilty, and orders JOC entered.

Court reviews letter that was sent to the Court by the defendant's mother. (Clerk provided copies to the parties in court)

Court sentences Mr. Wallace to 6 years, with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of 2 years, and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 4 years. This sentence is to commence FORTHWITH, concurrent to Jefferson County Case 13CM229.

The Court finds that the Defendant is eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program (Boot Camp) and the Substance Abuse Program. 
The Court gives 0 days credit for time already served.

The Court orders as conditions of Extended Supervision:
--AODA Assessment & Follow-through with any recommended treatment
--Any other assessment, treatment or counseling as required by the Agent
--Random Urinalyses or other drug testing (at least once per month for the first 2 years)
--Obtain/maintain employment and/or education program or combination of the two, as directed by the Agent
--No possession of controlled substances without a valid prescription
--No contact with any known drug offender except for treatment purposes and incidental contact for work or school purposes as approved by the agent
--To pay costs of $268
--To pay $250 DNA surcharge
--To reimburse $40 in buy money 
--To pay $25 drug testing fee

Felony Firearm and Voting-rights prohibitions/warnings given
Explanation of Determinate Sentence form given to the Defendant
recess: 2:36 pm
From non-party on behalf of the defendant
Copy of defendants bond showing the defendant refused to sign the bond
Request for detainer sent to dispatch & DCI w/fax confirmation
Preliminary hearing on June 10, 2014 at 02:00 pm.
Pre-trial conference on May 21, 2014 at 02:00 pm.
State's (with cover letter)
Defendant's
Attorney Elizabeth Svehlek

case called at 1:17pm. 
Defendant Matthew C. Wallace appears via videoconferencing from DCI, in custody, with Attorney Elizabeth Svehlek.  ADA  Monica Hall appears for the State of Wisconsin.  

On agreement of counsel, the Court finds that the videoconferencing system is sight and sound sufficient. 

Service of Complaint admitted, reading waived, the charge and maximum penalties are recited. 
Preliminary Hearing time limits are waived by both parties.

The Court requires a $2,500  signature bond, with conditions:
--no acts or threats of violence
--no possession or ingestion of controlled substances without a valid prescription
--no possession of drug paraphernalia without a valid prescription
--no direct or indirect contact with Sean Mueller
recess 1:18 pm. 


NEXT: (1) Pretrial Conference on May 21st at 2:00pm  (2) schedule Preliminary Hearing after the Pretrial date (State will need to prepare a writ)
